_comment: Created by ianb on 27/04/2015 18:00:41 using v2.5
title: How strongly do seasons influence breaches?
analysis_commentary: The impact of "winter pressures" on A&E performance against the four-hour target has been the subject of some debate. This chart shows weekly performance for major A&E units indexed to the start of the calendar year - so weeks 1 to 4 are January, weeks 5 to 8 are February and so on. There is a general trend for performance to be higher in the summer - despite the fact that A&E sees the highest numbers of attendees at this time. This is explained by changes in the case-mix of people attending. In summer A&E sees a higher proportion of cuts and sprains, most of which can be treated relatively quickly. A large dip in performance can be seen in the first 18 weeks of 2013. Performance trends appear more consistent towards the second-half of the year, although the 2014 data does not achieve a similar level and in fact declines dramatically towards the end of the year. So far in 2015 the performance of major A&E units has been consistently under 90%.
data_source: NHS England, A&E Waiting Times and Activity
